EQUISTAR Chemical Company

Channelview Operations (CVON)

8280 Sheldon Road

Channelview, TX 77530



Risk Management Plan Executive Summary - June 21, 2004





1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



At the EQUISTAR - Channelview Plant (CVON) we are committed to operating and maintaining our processes to protect our employees, the public, and the environment.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure continued operations with protection in environmental, health and safety (EHS) protection in mind.  This document provides a  brief overview of our comprehensive rick management activities to prevent or eliminate the possibilityof an acidental relase of a regulated chemical.



It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent the relase of a regulated substance, however, if such a release does occur, our trained emergency response personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of any release.   We are also coordinated with the Houston area's Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) which provides additional emergency response expertise.





2.0 Stationary Source  and Regulated Substances



Our facility cracks Naptha, OP-400, and Algerian condensates into a number of products that include 1,3-Butadiene, Isobutylene/Butene, Isoprene, Propylene, Isobutane and other olefins.  In addition, Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether (MTBE) and an assortment of products are produced in the Mid Plant unit, including Methanol and Isopropanol.  There are two Olefins Cracking units and one East Plant/Mid Plant manufacturing unit.  These operating units utilize the following chemicals that have been identifed by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequencees in the event of their substantial accidental release:





Flammables



Propylene: Approximately 1,500,000 lbs. are stored and used on-site.  Propylene is refined in the Olefins.



Olef

ins Condensate: Approximately 112 million lbs. of mixed condensate feedstocks, intermediates, and products are present within the Olefins process units and in the tank farm area.  The condensates include Algerian, OP-400, and Naptha condensate materials, depending in most part to the supplier.  





Isobutylene: Approximately 1.1 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant process unit.  Isobutylene is an intermediate chemical used in the production of MTBE.



1,3-Butadiene: Approximately 3.5 million pounds of Butadiene are stored and in process within the East Plant.  Butadiene is further utilized on the Poly-Butadiene process are within the Mid Plant as well as sold as a finished product.



N-Butane: Approximately 1.3 million lbs. are contained in storage and within the East Plant process unit.  N-Butane is an intermediate chemical and is sent to the Olefins Cracking Units for further processing.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.



Regulated Flammable Chemicals



Worst-Case Scenario - Olefins Condensate Storage Tank (Flammable Mixture)



The worst-case scenario for flammables assumes the complete rupture of the isobutylene surge drum, releasing 26,620,000 lbs. of this flammable mixture into a diked area, leading to a vapor cloud explosion and overpressure.  The overpressure would extend beyond the fenceline 2.4mi. and affect approximately 6,000 people.



Alternate Release Scenario - Propylene



The alternate release scenario for flammables assumes a mechanical failure of a valve on the 4th stage suction drum on the Olefins 2 Propylene refrigeration system, resulting in a release of the entire compressor circuit.  The scenario also assumes that the release would not be controlled for 15 minutes and that all active safety systems fail.  The total release wou

ld be approximately 800,000 lbs. of Propylene, leading to a vapor cloud explosion and overpressure.  The over pressure would not be contained on-site, traveling for 0.5 miles.  The total affected poppulation would be approximately 600 people.





General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



EQUISTAR Chemicals - Channelview Operations (CVON) has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth under 40 CFR Part 68.  Addiitonally, this facility was designed and constructed in accordance with strict internal engineering standards as well as is subject to the requirements under 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management.



Process Safety Information: Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, kept up-to-date, and made available to operating personnel.



Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs): A rigorous practice of reviewing new processes or changes to existing processes at the design stage, with the overall thougth of identifying and mitigating HSE issues before installation or operation.  Scheduled PHAs are conducted every 5 years to revalidate previous hazard reviews and recommend corrective actions to prevent accidents.



Operating Procedures: Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are kept up-to-date constantly thru a review during any SOP training opportunity.  Operating procedures are based on process hazard / risk reviews and are periodically modified after completed of a process PHA.  Operating procedures include safe start-up and emergency shutdown of a process unit.



Operator Training / Certification Program: CVON has a training and testing program that ensures that operators have the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.  Periodic operator re-certification is required.



Computerized Process Simulation: Computerized simulation programs are used for tr

aining and troubleshooting and include emergency shutdown and start-up simulations.



Maintenance Procedures: CVON has specific procedures for maintaining process equiment so that it operates safely.  Plant and unit spefific proceduresfor servicing operating equipment are in place, including a preventive / predictive maintenance and reliability programs.



Maintenance Training: CVON trains and test mechanics and other craftsmen who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment and inspections on operating equipment to ensure they have the required knowledge and skills.



Mechanical Integrity Program: Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment, are periodically tested and inspected to ensure safe operations, following recognized standards and governmental requirements.  



Quality Assurance: CVON has a system to ensure that purchased equipment and materials meet established engineering standards and specifications.



Process Change Authorizations (Management of Change / PCAs): CVON has a management sytem to ensure that modifications to a process or faclities are evaluated to ensure continued safe operations.  Design (DSRs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are conducted for facility or process changes prior to implementation of the change.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs): Reviews conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities or processes are safe to operate.



Incident Investigation: CVON has a program to ensure that accidents, incidents, and near misses are properly investigated to determine the root cause as well as contributing causes.  In addition to the investigation, action items resulting from the investigation are communicated site-wide and tracked to completion to prevent recurrence.



Compliance Audits: CVON conducts audits on a regular basis to verify the provisions set forth under the PSM and RMP rules are being implemented.  These audits are conducted at a minimum of ever

y three years.



Employee Participation: CVON plant has a program to ensure that maintenance and operations personnel are involved in all prevention program elements.  Each operating area also has a representative on the Plant Safety Committee.



Contractor Safety Program: The plant has a program to ensure that contractors are properly trained, and uses the Houston Area Contractors Association as a tool to provide the basic HSE training required of a contractor prior to entering a chemical manufacturing facility.  All contractor employees must attend the Houston Area Contractors Association training and be certified through examination prior to arriving at the plant.  In addition to basic training CVON site specific training is required prior to arriving at the plant.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of specific substances regulated under the RMP rule at this facility over the last 5 years.  However, there was a release of Benzene from the Benzene NESHAPS tank on July 28, 2001 that resulted in an off-site impact and the closure of roads along the CVON facility.  The NRC case number for this incident was #574651.  Benzene is not listed specifically as a toxic, and the mixture in the NESHAPS tank is not flammable, that is why the incident was not identified in the resubmitted RMP, but rather put here in the Executive Summary.  As a result of the incident investigation, there were 6 action items to prevent recurrence of this incident and all were completed during the Olefins 1&2 Turnarounds in 2003



Emergency Response



CVON maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  This program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, CVON coordinates with the community response plan through the North Channel

and Highlands LEPC, as well as the Harris County Office of Emergency Management.  CVON is also a participating member of the Houston area Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of improvements CVON is planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



* Continued review and upgrade of safety interlocks system.

* Revalidate all PHAs in accordance with requirementns under RMP and PSM.

* Revise the emergency response plan after critiques from recent drills.

* Update facility security with a Security and Vulnerability Survey.

* Continue to utilize the tools of Root Cause Analysis to investigate incidents and develop effective solutions to prevent recurrence.
